Michael Adebowale | motive = Retaliation for British military's presence in Islamic countries }} On the afternoon of 22 May 2013, a [[British Army]] soldier, [[Fusilier#United Kingdom|Fusilier]] '''Lee Rigby''' of the [[Royal Regiment of Fusiliers]], was attacked and killed by Michael Adebolajo and Michael Adebowale near the [[Royal Artillery Barracks]] in [[Woolwich]], southeast London.{{cite web|title=Woolwich attack: Killed man 'was soldier'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22634468#TWEET765325|publisher=BBC News|date=23 May 2013|accessdate=23 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=Woolwich attack victim confirmed as serving soldier|publisher=Ministry of Defence, Prime Ministers Office, Home Office|date=23 May 2013|accessdate=23 May 2013|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/woolwich-attack-victim-confirmed-as-serving-soldier}}{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/news/britain/21578453-shocking-killing-reminder-disorganised-jihadists-are-harder-stop-organised|title=An atrocity in London: Return to old-style terror|date=25 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-05-31/woolwich-terrorist-attack3a-lee-rigby-inquest-begins-as-queen-/4727090|title=Woolwich terrorist attack: Lee Rigby inquest begins as Queen Elizabeth pays tribute|date=1 June 2013|publisher=ABC News}}{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/woolwich-murder-with-universal-condemnation-comes-the-need-for-wise-action-8636145.html|title=Woolwich murder: With universal condemnation comes the need for wise action|date=29 May 2013|newspaper=The Independent}} Rigby was off duty and walking along Wellington Street when he was attacked.{{cite web|title=Man killed in deadly terror attack in London street|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/22/police-respond-serious-incident-woolwich|work=The Guardian|last=Dodd|first=Vikram|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}} Adebolajo and Adebowale ran him down with a car, then used knives and a [[cleaver]] to stab and hack him to death.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10074881/Mum-talked-down-Woolwich-terrorists-who-told-her-We-want-to-start-a-war-in-London-tonight.html|title=Mum talked down Woolwich terrorists who told her: 'We want to start a war in London tonight'|first=Claire|last=Duffin|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=23 May 2013}} The men dragged Rigby's body into the road and remained at the scene until police arrived. They told passers-by that they had killed a soldier to avenge the killing of Muslims by the British armed forces.{{cite web|title=Woolwich machete attack leaves man dead|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22630303|publisher=BBC News|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}} [[Police use of firearms in the United Kingdom|Unarmed police]] arrived at the scene nine minutes after an emergency call was received and set up a cordon. Armed police officers arrived five minutes later. The assailants, armed with a cleaver and brandishing a gun, charged at the police, who fired shots that wounded them both. They were apprehended and taken to separate hospitals. Adebolajo and Adebowale are [[British Nigerian|British of Nigerian descent]], were raised as Christians, and converted to Islam.[http://news.sky.com/story/1094560/woolwich-suspects-known-to-security-services Woolwich Suspects 'Known To Security Services'], Sky, 23 May 2013 On 19 December 2013, both of the attackers were found guilty of Rigby's murder. On 26 February 2014, they were sentenced to [[life imprisonment]], with Adebolajo given a [[Whole life tariff|whole life order]] and Adebowale ordered to serve at least 45 years. The attack was condemned by political and Muslim leaders in the United Kingdom and in the international press.{{cite news |title=UK Muslim groups condemn London slaying, urge leaders to act|first=Laura|last=Smith-Spark|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/05/23/world/europe/uk-attack-muslims|publisher=CNN|date=24 May 2013|accessdate=24 May 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22653147|title=World press condemns Woolwich killing|date=24 May 2013|publisher=BBC}} ==Victim== [[File:Drummer Lee Rigby 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Fusilier Lee Rigby of the 2nd Battalion Royal Fusiliers]] The soldier killed in the attack was 25-year-old Lee Rigby, a drummer and machine-gunner in the 2nd Battalion of the [[Royal Regiment of Fusiliers]]. Rigby, from [[Middleton, Greater Manchester]], had served in Cyprus, Germany, and Afghanistan before becoming a recruiter and assisting with duties in the [[Tower of London]].{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22644857|title=Woolwich attack: Lee Rigby named as victim|publisher=BBC News |date=23 May 2013|location=London|accessdate=23 May 2013}}{{cite news|title=Woolwich soldier murder victim named as Lee Rigby from Middleton|first=Dan|last=Thompson|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/woolwich-soldier-murder-victim-named-4007798|newspaper=[[Manchester Evening News]]|date=23 May 2013|accessdate=23 May 2013}}{{cite web|last=Shaviv |first=Miriam |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/military-calls-uk-attack-victim-a-model-soldier/ |title=UK military calls attack victim a model soldier|work=The Times of Israel|date=23 May 2013}} He was attacked when he was returning to barracks from working at the Tower.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby inquest: Soldier had been working at Tower of London on day of death|first1=Margaret|last1=Davis|first2=Ellen|last2=Branagh|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/lee-rigby-inquest-soldier-had-been-working-at-tower-of-london-on-day-of-death-8638835.html|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=31 May 2013|accessdate=2 June 2013}} Rigby married in 2007 and had a two-year-old son, but had separated from his wife.Silverman, Rosa. (23 May 2013) [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10076791/Soldier-murdered-in-Woolwich-named-as-Drummer-Lee-Rigby.html Soldier murdered in Woolwich]. ''The Daily Telegraph''. He was engaged to a new fiancée at the time of his death.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby's fiancée says she is 'devastated' by the soldier's death|first=Paul|last=Britton|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/lee-rigbys-fiance-says-devastated-4028735|newspaper=[[Manchester Evening News]]|date=29 May 2013|accessdate=2 June 2013}} A [[autopsy|post-mortem examination]] showed that Rigby died from "multiple incised wounds".{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22703063|title=Woolwich murder: Lee Rigby 'had multiple wounds'|date=29 May 2013|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 May 2013}} Rigby supported British Armed Forces charity [[Help for Heroes]]{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Rigby|title=Lee's Page|url=http://www.justgiving.com/Lee-Rigby|publisher=Just giving.|accessdate=3 June 2013}} and was wearing a [[hoodie]] supporting the charity when he was attacked.{{cite news|last=Fletcher|first=Damien|title=Woolwich attack: Watch Drummer Lee Rigby grab a takeaway in poignant last known footage of him alive|url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/woolwich-attack-watch-drummer-lee-1909838|accessdate=19 August 2013|newspaper=mirror.co.uk|date=25 May 2013}} In the five days after his death the charity received more than £600,000 in donations.{{cite news|last=Pudelek|first=Jenna|title=Donations of £600,000 made to Help for Heroes since murder of soldier|url=http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/Fundraising/article/1183999/donations-600000-made-help-heroes-murder-soldier/|accessdate=3 June 2013|date=28 May 2013}} Rigby was given a [[military funeral]] at [[Church of St Mary the Virgin, Bury|Bury Parish Church]] on 12 July 2013. The service was attended by several thousand people, including present and former soldiers, Prime Minister [[David Cameron]], and Mayor of London [[Boris Johnson]]. A private burial service was then held at nearby Middleton Cemetery.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby: Military funeral for killed soldier|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-23263754|accessdate=12 July 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=12 July 2013}} The first permanent memorial to him was installed in February 2014 at [[The Valley (London)|The Valley]], a football stadium less than {{convert|1|mi}} from the site of his murder.{{cite news|title=Football fans install first permanent memorial to murdered soldier Lee Rigby|url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/charlton-athletic-fans-lee-rigby-3176313|accessdate=2 September 2014|work=Daily Mirror|date=23 February 2014}} ==Attack== [[File:2013 Woolwich attack map.PNG|thumb|upright|Location of the attack, indicated by the arrow, outside the [[Royal Artillery Barracks]]]] The attack took place shortly before 14:20 in Wellington Street, and near its junction with John Wilson Street, part of the [[South Circular Road, London|South Circular Road]] (A205) in Woolwich, near the perimeter of the [[Royal Artillery Barracks]] where Rigby was stationed. Rigby had arrived at [[Woolwich Arsenal station]] at 14:10 and was walking down Wellington Street towards the Barracks.{{cite news|title=Terrorists guilty of killing soldier Lee Rigby|url=http://courtnewsuk.co.uk/newsgallery/?page=10&news_id=35385|accessdate=13 January 2014|publisher=Court News|date=19 December 2013}}{{cite news|title=This CCTV image issued Thursday Dec. 19, 2013 from the Metropolitan Police|url=http://news.yahoo.com/photos/cctv-image-issued-thursday-dec-19-2013-metropolitan-photo-172959615.html|accessdate=13 January 2014|publisher=Yahoo News|date=19 December 2013}} While Rigby was crossing the road to get to a shop, two men, who were later identified as Michael Adebolajo and Michael Adebowale, drove a [[Opel Tigra|Vauxhall Tigra]] car at him at {{convert|30|to|40|mph|km/h|sigfig=1}}, knocking him to the ground.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby murder timeline, by prosecution|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/10483853/Lee-Rigby-murder-timeline-by-prosecution.html|accessdate=13 January 2014|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=29 November 2013}}{{cite web|author1=Laville, Sandra |author2=Malik, Shiv |author3=Quinn, Ben |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/22/woolwich-attack-horror-soldier|title=Woolwich killing: horror on John Wilson Street|work=The Guardian|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}} They attacked Rigby with knives and a cleaver, and attempted to [[Beheading in Islamism|behead]] him.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10073910/Woolwich-attack-terrorist-proclaimed-an-eye-for-an-eye-after-attack.html |title=Woolwich attack| newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=24 May 2013| accessdate=24 May 2013| first1=Gordon|first2=Steven|last1=Rayner |last2=Swinford}} Immediately after the attack, several passers-by stood over Rigby's body to protect him from further injury. Ingrid Loyau-Kennett, a cub scout leader from Cornwall, disembarked from a passing bus with the intention of rendering first aid, after she saw what she thought was a road accident. On discovering that the victim was dead she engaged one of the assailants in conversation. The man said he was responsible for killing the man on the ground – a British soldier who the attacker claimed had "killed Muslims in Iraq and in Afghanistan".{{cite news|last=Hickman|first=Leo|title=Woolwich attack witness Ingrid Loyau-Kennett: 'I feel like a fraud'|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/27/woolwich-witness-ingrid-loyau-kennett|accessdate=27 May 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 May 2013}}{{cite web|first=Ingrid|last=Loyau-Kennetto|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10075028/Woolwich-attacker-told-me-he-wanted-to-start-a-war-says-woman-who-confronted-knifeman.html|title=Woolwich attacker told me he 'wanted to start a war', says woman who confronted knifeman|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=27 May 2013}} She asked one of the men to hand over his weapons, but he refused.{{Cite news|last=Duffin|first=Claire|title=Mum talked down Woolwich terrorists who told her: 'We want to start a war in London tonight'|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=22 May 2013|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10074881/Mum-talked-down-Woolwich-terrorists-who-told-her-We-want-to-start-a-war-in-London-tonight.html}} In a video shot by a bystander, Adebolajo said: {{quote|The only reason we have killed this man today is because Muslims are dying daily by British soldiers. And this British soldier is one … By Allah, we swear by the almighty Allah we will never stop fighting you until you leave us alone. So what if we want to live by the Sharia in Muslim lands? Why does that mean you must follow us and chase us and call us extremists and kill us? … when you drop a bomb do you think it hits one person? Or rather your bomb wipes out a whole family? … Through many passages in the Koran we must fight them as they fight us … I apologise that women had to witness this today but in our lands women have to see the same. You people will never be safe. Remove your governments, they don’t care about you. You think David Cameron is gonna get caught in the street when we start busting our guns? Do you think politicians are going to die? No, it's going to be the average guy, like you and your children. So get rid of them. Tell them to bring our troops back … leave our lands and you will live in peace.|Excerpted from a ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]'' transcript{{cite web|title=Woolwich attack: the terrorist's rant|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10075488/Woolwich-attack-the-terrorists-rant.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=1 June 2013|date=23 May 2013}} }} Adebolajo also gave a bystander at the scene a handwritten two-page note which set out his justification for his actions.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby murder: Killer Michael Adebolajo handed witness a note attempting to justify actions|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/lee-rigby-murder-killer-michael-adebolajo-handed-witness-a-note-attempting-to-justify-actions-9015775.html|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=23 December 2013|date=19 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Court sees Rigby suspects shooting footage (images 9 and 10)|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-25201524|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=23 December 2013|date=3 December 2013}} The assailants remained at the scene and asked bystanders to call the police.BBC News, (23 May 2013) [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22636231 "Woolwich attack: Eyewitness accounts"] The [[Metropolitan Police]] received the first [[999 (emergency telephone number)|999 call]] about an assault at 14:20 and unarmed police were deployed. Subsequent 999 calls said the attackers had a firearm, and armed police were ordered to the scene at 14:24. Unarmed police arrived at 14:29, set up a cordon, and remained behind it.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/23/david-cameron-woolwich-killing-police |title=Woolwich attack will only make us stronger, says Cameron|newspaper=The Guardian|date=23 May 2013|last1=Jones|last2=Laville|last3=Walker|first1=Sam|first2=Sandra|first3=Peter}} [[Authorised Firearms Officer]]s arrived at 14:34. Two men, one brandishing a cleaver and the other a revolver, charged at the police. Armed police fired eight times and both men were wounded.{{cite web|author1=Rath, Kayte |author2=Wallis, Holly |author3=Tooth, Martin |publisher=BBC|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22653593|place=UK|title=Woolwich aftermath as it happened|date=24 May 2013}} They were arrested and taken to separate hospitals. A revolver, knives, and a cleaver were seized at the scene. The victim, Rigby, was pronounced dead and formally identified. The revolver was later determined to be a non-functioning 90-year-old Dutch [[Royal Netherlands East Indies Army|KNIL]] 9.4mm.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/10607238/Criminals-resorting-to-antique-guns-as-authorities-crack-down-on-firearm-smuggling-say-police.html |title=Criminals resorting to antique guns as authorities crack down on firearm smuggling, say police |publisher=Telegraph |date=2014-01-30 |accessdate=2015-10-11}} Adebowale pointed the gun at responding armed police officers, who opened fire and shot off one of his thumbs.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/10491566/Lee-Rigby-trial-police-woman-thought-she-was-going-to-die-as-man-ran-at-her-with-meat-cleaver-court-hears.html|title=Lee Rigby trial: police woman thought she was going to die as man ran at her with meat cleaver, court hears|work=Daily Telegraph |date=3 December 2013 |accessdate=11 October 2015}} {{clear}} ==Attackers and other suspects== The two men who carried out the attack, '''Michael Olumide Adebolajo''', 28, and '''Michael Oluwatobi Adebowale''', 22,, Laville, Sandra; Walker, Peter; Dodd, Vikram (23 May 2013) [http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/23/woolwich-attack-suspect-michael-adebolajo "Woolwich Attack Suspect Michael Adebolajo"] ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 25 May 2013 are [[British Nigerian|British of Nigerian descent]].{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887324659404578502790328797014.html|title=Second Suspect in London Attack Named|date=24 May 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|author=Cassell Bryan-Low}} Both men were known to British security services.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22634468|title=Woolwich attack: Suspects known to security services|date=23 May 2013|accessdate=23 May 2013|publisher=BBC News}} On 23 May, a man aged 29 and two women aged 31 and 29 were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to murder.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22677733 |title=Woolwich murder: Three men released on bail|date=27 May 2013|publisher=BBC News}} The Metropolitan Police arrested three people aged between 21 and 28 in south-east London, at two separate locations on the evening of 25 May.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22670375 "Woolwich murder probe: Three more arrests"]. BBC News, 25 May 2013 On 26 May, a 22-year-old male was arrested in [[Highbury]]. On 27 May, a 50-year-old male was arrested in [[Welling]].{{cite web|title=Woolwich: The investigation|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22658398|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=28 May 2013|date=28 May 2013}} Of the eight people arrested, six were freed on bail, and two released without charge.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22712411|title=Lee Rigby killing: Man to be charged|publisher=BBC News|date=29 May 2013|accessdate=29 May 2013}} ===Michael Adebolajo=== Adebolajo, born in [[Lambeth]] to a Christian family,{{cite news |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22636624 |title=Woolwich murder: who are the suspects? |publisher=BBC News |date= 24 May 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2013}}{{cite news |url= http://news.sky.com/story/1094560/woolwich-terror-murder-suspect-named |title=Woolwich Terror Murder Suspect Named |publisher=BSkyB |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=23 May 2013}} went to [[Marshalls Park School]] and studied sociology at the [[University of Greenwich]]. He has a history of involvement in radical Islamist activities and had been arrested at a violent protest and later released.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10077439/Woolwich-attack-why-was-suspect-Michael-Adebolajo-free-to-kill.html|title=Woolwich attack: why was suspect Michael Adebolajo free to kill?|date=23 May 2013|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|author1=Whitehead, Tom |author2=Barrett, David |author3=Swinford, Steven }} According to [[Anjem Choudary]], a radical Muslim cleric, Adebolajo converted to [[Islam]] in 2003 and was linked to the outlawed Islamist group [[al-Muhajiroun]].{{cite news|author=Sengupta, Kim|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/man-and-woman-arrested-on-suspicion-of-conspiracy-to-murder-victim-of-woolwich-machete-attack-named-as-drummer-lee-rigby-8628583.html|title=Man and woman arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to murder victim of Woolwich machete attack, named as Drummer Lee Rigby |work=The Independent |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=23 May 2013}} In 2006, Adebolajo was arrested outside the [[Old Bailey]] during a protest about the trial of [[Mizanur Rahman (islamic activist)|Mizanur Rahman]].{{cite news|last=Whitehead|first=Tom|title=Woolwich attack: Suspect Michael 'Mujahid' Adebolajo led away in handcuffs at fanatic’s trial|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10077471/Woolwich-attack-Suspect-Michael-Mujahid-Adebolajo-led-away-in-handcuffs-at-fanatics-trial.html|accessdate=28 May 2013|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=23 May 2013}} In 2009, Adebolajo spoke at a demonstration against the [[English Defence League]] and [[Stop Islamisation of Europe]] organised by [[Unite Against Fascism]] at [[Harrow Central Mosque]]. He was recorded saying: "Don't be scared of them, do not be scared of the police or the cameras. You are here only to please Allah. You're not here for any other reason, if you are here just for a fight, please leave our ranks. We only want those who are sincere to Allah. Purify your intention."{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2013-05-29/new-footage-of-woolwich-suspect-michael-adebolajo-speaking-at-a-demonstration-in-2009/|title=Footage of Woolwich suspect leading protest|date=29 May 2013|publisher=ITV}} In 2010, Adebolajo was arrested in Kenya with five others. He travelled using a British passport in the name Michael Olemendis Ndemolajo.{{cite news|last1=Odula |first1=Tom| last2=Hui |first2=Sylvia|title=KENYA: UK SOLDIER KILLING SUSPECT ARRESTED IN 2010|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/uk-sets-task-force-target-radical-preachers|work=Associated Press|accessdate=26 May 2013}} Boniface Mwaniki, head of Kenya's anti-terrorism unit, said he believed Adebolajo was planning to train with [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]], a militant group linked to [[al-Qaeda]]. He was released to British authorities in Kenya and deported. The British Foreign Office confirmed "a British national was arrested in Kenya in 2010" and was given consular assistance. No charges were filed against Adebolajo.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby murder: Police make 10th arrest|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-22679755|accessdate=28 May 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=28 May 2013}} Abu Nusaybah, a friend of Adebolajo, said on BBC's ''[[Newsnight]]'' on 25 May that Adebolajo had complained of persistent questioning by the British Security Service ([[MI5]]) specifically concerning his knowledge of "certain individuals". He said Adebolajo alleged that MI5 had asked him to work with them and he had refused.Urquhart, Conal; Dodd, Vikram (25 May 2013). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/25/woolwich-suspect-kenya-torture "Woolwich suspect's friend arrested after appearing on ''Newsnight''"]. ''The Guardian''.{{cite news|title=Woolwich attack: MI5 'offered job to suspect'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22664468|accessdate=25 May 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=25 May 2013}} He also said Adebolajo claimed he had been tortured and sexually assaulted by Kenyan troops after his arrest.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10080318/Woolwich-attack-Michael-Adebolajo-was-asked-to-work-for-MI5-claims-friend.html|title=Woolwich attack: Michael Adebolajo was asked to work for MI5 claims friend|date=25 May 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=25 November 2014}} Adebolajo was released from hospital on 31 May and taken into police custody.{{cite web|title=Woolwich: Michael Adebolajo discharged from hospital|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22734302|publisher=BBC News|date=31 May 2013|accessdate=31 May 2013}} The following day he was charged with Rigby's murder, two charges of attempting to murder police officers, and possession of a firearm.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22743438|title=Woolwich: Michael Adebolajo charged with Lee Rigby murder |publisher=BBC News|date=1 June 2013 |accessdate=1 June 2013}} At a court appearance on 3 June, he asked to be known as Mujahid Abu Hamza.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22748021 |title=Woolwich murder suspects remanded in custody|publisher=BBC News |date=3 June 2013 |accessdate=3 June 2013}} On 17 July, Adebolajo lost two of his front teeth while being restrained by five prison officers at [[Belmarsh prison]]. The officers were suspended from duty.{{cite news|title=Michael Adebolajo injuries: prison officers deny wrongdoing |url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/jul/19/michael-adebolajo-injuries-prison-officers|accessdate=19 July 2013|publisher=The Guardian|date=19 July 2013}}{{cite news|title=No charges for prison officers accused of assaulting Michael Adebolajo|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/dec/19/michael-adebolajo-assault-prison-officers-no-charges|accessdate=19 December 2013|publisher=The Guardian|date=19 December 2013}} ===Michael Adebowale=== Following media reports that Michael Adebowale had attended the [[University of Greenwich]] with Michael Adebolajo, the university issued a statement, in which it said that there were "no records relating to [Adebowale] in connection with the Woolwich incident", and that the university had launched an investigation into the matter.{{cite news|title=Woolwich soldier killing suspects Michael Adebowale and Michael Adebolajo 'attended Greenwich University together'|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/woolwich-soldier-killing-suspects-michael-adebowale-and-michael-adebolajo-attended-greenwich-university-together-8631056.html|date=24 May 2013|first=Rob|last= Williams|accessdate=24 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Independent]]}}[http://www2.gre.ac.uk/about/news/articles/2013/statementbarrackevents Statement following the incident in Woolwich]. [[University of Greenwich]], 25 May 2013. Retrieved 16 December 2013. Adebolawe's mother is a [[probation officer]] and his father a member of staff at the [[High Commission of Nigeria, London|Nigerian High Commission]].{{cite news|last=Ensor|first=Josie|title=Woolwich attack: Michael Adebowale's mother 'tried to prevent radicalisation'|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10079781/Woolwich-attack-Michael-Adebowales-mother-tried-to-prevent-radicalisation.html|accessdate=25 May 2013|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=24 May 2013|author2=Malnick, Edward|author3=Evans, Martin}} On 28 May, Adebowale was released from hospital and taken to a police station in south London.{{cite news|title=Woolwich: Michael Adebowale discharged from hospital|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22695595|accessdate=28 May 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=28 May 2013}} Police charged him with the murder of Rigby and possession of a firearm. ==Investigation== Investigators searched four houses in [[Greenwich]], south London; one in [[Romford]], east London; another in north London; and a property in [[Saxilby]], Lincolnshire.{{cite web|title=Woolwich murder: Lincolnshire arrest over social media posts|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-22656549|date=24 May 2013|accessdate=24 May 2013|publisher=BBC News}} Sir [[Malcolm Rifkind]], the chairman of the [[Intelligence and Security Committee]], said the committee would use new powers to retrieve documents from intelligence agencies. A written report is to be provided by [[Andrew Parker (MI5 officer)|Andrew Parker]], the [[Director General of MI5]].{{cite news|work=The Independent|last1=Glover| first1=Mike |last2=Brady |first2=Brian| last3=Owen |first3=Jonathan |last4=Cahalan |first4=Paul | last5=Bignell |first5=Paul|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/mi5-tried-to-recruit-woolwich-attack-suspect-michael-adebolajo-8632398.html |title=Woolwich attack: Terror suspect Michael Adebolajo was arrested in Kenya on suspicion of being at centre of al-Qa'ida-inspired plot|date= 26 May 2013| accessdate=27 May 2013}} An [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] investigation{{cite web|title=MPS – Woolwich firearms incident|url=http://www.ipcc.gov.uk/investigations/mps-woolwich-firearms-incident|publisher=[[Independent Police Complaints Commission]]|accessdate=23 December 2013}} into the use of firearms by [[Metropolitan Police]] Officers, which was published on 19 December 2013 once a [[verdict]] had been reached in the defendants' trial, concluded that the officers who had used force on 22 May 2013 had "acted entirely appropriately" and had shown "skill and professionalism".{{cite web|title=IPCC investigation concludes Metropolitan Police firearms officers acted appropriately to dangerous situation in Woolwich|url=http://www.ipcc.gov.uk/news/ipcc-investigation-concludes-metropolitan-police-firearms-officers-acted-appropriately|publisher=[[Independent Police Defence Secretary [[Philip Hammond]], the Mayor of London Boris Johnson, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir [[Bernard Hogan-Howe]], the Metropolitan Police Assistant Commissioner [[Cressida Dick]] and other unnamed members of the intelligence agencies. The Prime Minister David Cameron cut short a visit to Paris to chair a second COBRA meeting. ==Legal proceedings== On 31 May, the [[Inquest (England and Wales)|inquest]] into Rigby's death was opened and adjourned at [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark]] Coroner's Court. The inquest heard that Rigby had been identified by his [[forensic dentistry|dental records]]. On 27 September 2013, the two accused men appeared via videolink in court at the [[Old Bailey]], where they both pleaded not guilty to the murder of Lee Rigby, and to other charges relating to the incident.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24297429 |title=Two plead not guilty to Rigby murder |publisher=BBC News |date=27 September 2013}} The trial began at the Old Bailey on 29 November 2013. Adebolajo asked to be known as Mujaahid Abu Hamza in court with Adebowale wishing to be known as Ismail Ibn Abdullah.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-25153273 |title=Lee Rigby trial: Killing 'cowardly and callous', court hears |publisher=BBC News |date=29 November 2013}} On 19 December 2013, Michael Adebolajo and Michael Adebowale were found guilty of the murder of Lee Rigby. The judge, [[Nigel Sweeney|Mr Justice Sweeney]], said that he would pass [[Sentence (law)|sentence]] after a key appeal court ruling on the use of [[Whole life tariff|whole life terms]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-25450555 |title=Two guilty of Lee Rigby murder|publisher=BBC News |date=19 December 2013}} On 26 February 2014, both men were sentenced to [[life imprisonment]]. Adebolajo was given a whole life order excluding the possibility of parole, and Adebowale, the younger of the two, was given a minimum term of 45 years in prison.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26357007 |work=BBC News |title=Lee Rigby murder: Adebolajo and Adebowale jailed |publisher=BBC |date=26 February 2014 |accessdate=26 February 2014}} During the sentencing, Mr Justice Sweeney said that the extremist views of the attackers were a "betrayal of Islam", prompting Adebowale to shout "That’s a lie", while Adebolajo shouted "''[[Allahu Akbar]]''".{{cite news|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/woolwich-adeboloajo-adebowale-lee-rigby-murder-sentence |work=Channel 4 News |title=Woolwich attack: life for Lee Rigby killers |publisher=Channel 4 |date=26 February 2014 |accessdate=8 April 2014}} Following a scuffle with security guards in the dock, both men were removed from the court and the sentencing continued in their absence. On 8 April 2014, Adebolajo launched an appeal against his whole life term.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26941996 |work=BBC News |title=Lee Rigby killer Michael Adebolajo launches appeal |publisher=BBC |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=8 April 2014}} On 29 July, he was refused permission to appeal, and the case was heard by a panel of [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]] judges.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-28544262|work=BBC News |title=Michael Adebolajo loses first part of Rigby murder appeal |publisher=BBC |date=29 July 2014 |accessdate=1 August 2014}} In July 2014, a [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|freedom of information request]] filed by ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' showed that Adebolajo and Adebowale had received a combined £212,613.32 in [[legal aid]]. On 3 December 2014, Rigby's killers lost legal challenges to their sentences. Michael Adebolajo had attempted to have his conviction overturned and whole-life sentence reduced, while Michael Adebowale attempted a reduction in his minimum sentence of 45 years. Both requests were rejected at the Court of Appeal.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-30306145|title=Lee Rigby murder: Killer loses legal challenge|publisher=BBC News|date=3 December 2014}} ==Subsequent events== [[File:Drummer Lee Rigby flowers at Woolwich on the 30 May 2013.jpeg|thumb|The site of the attack in Wellington Street, with floral tributes and flags, 30 May 2013]] The [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] investigated the incident. Immediately after the death, British service members were advised not to wear military uniforms in public,{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10075476/Woolwich-attack-troops-advised-not-to-wear-uniform-outside-bases.html|title=Woolwich attack: troops advised not to wear uniform outside bases|date=24 May 2013|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|first=Ben |last=Farmer}} although the advice was later relaxed.{{cite web|last1=Wyatt |first1=Caroline|authorlink1=Caroline Wyatt|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22642441 |title=Woolwich attack will not stop soldiers wearing uniforms |publisher=BBC News |date=23 May 2013}} In the immediate aftermath, Julie Siddiqi of the [[Islamic Society of Britain]] expressed concern that the killing would be used to create ethnic and community divisions.{{cite web|first=Ross|last=Lydall|url=http://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/woolwich-killing-plea-for-calm-as-mosques-are-targeted-and-english-defence-league-and-police-clash-8628387.html|title=Woolwich killing: plea for calm as mosques are targeted and English Defence League clash with police|work=Evening Standard |location=London|accessdate=23 May 2013}} Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe condemned the attack and called for a calm and "measured response", adding "we have met with community representatives, and extra officers remain on duty there tonight. Across London our officers are in contact with their communities too." Commander Simon Letchford later noted community concerns following the incident and assured that an investigation was under way. He also appealed for calm and avoidance of speculation.{{cite web|author1=Paul Owen |author2=Conal Urquhart |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/22/woolwich-two-shot-in-police-incident-live-coverage|title=Woolwich attack: government convenes emergency meeting|work=The Guardian|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=22 May 2013}} An additional 1,200 police officers were deployed across London to prevent revenge attacks on Muslim communities.{{cite news|title=UK names soldier murdered in London|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/05/2013523141437691602.html|accessdate=23 May 2013|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=23 May 2013}} The [[British National Party]] (BNP) leader, [[Nick Griffin]], posted a series of Twitter messages blaming "mass immigration" for the attack and called for a protest rally in Woolwich.{{cite web|first1=Sam|last1=Jones|first2=Ben|last2=Quinn|first3=Conal|last3=Urquhart|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/23/woolwich-attack-backlash-british-muslims|title=Woolwich attack prompts fears of backlash against British Muslims|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=23 May 2013|date=23 May 2013}} After the [[English Defence League]] called on its supporters to mobilise, some members staged a protest at [[Woolwich Arsenal station]] in which bottles were thrown at police. The BNP scheduled their protest for 1 June, but Scotland Yard refused to permit them to march from Woolwich Barracks; the demonstration instead took place at [[Whitehall]] in central London.{{cite news|first=Kevin |last=Rawlinson |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/woolwich-attacks-bnp-and-antifascists-in-street-clashes-8640798.html |title=Woolwich attacks: BNP and anti-fascists in street clashes |publisher=Independent Print Limited |newspaper=The Independent |date=2 June 2013 |accessdate=5 June 2013}} [[Unite Against Fascism]] mounted a counter-protest. Police arrested 58 people, all anti-fascist protesters, for breaches of the [[Public Order Act 1986|Public Order Act]].{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22739189 |title=Fifty-eight arrested during Westminster protests |work=BBC News |date=1 June 2013}} On 7 June 2013, a 21-year-old woman from [[Harrow, London|Harrow]] was ordered to complete 250 hours of unpaid work after tweeting that people in Help for Heroes T-shirts "deserve to be beheaded".{{cite news|title=Woolwich attack: Student sentenced for 'joke' tweet|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-22821484|accessdate=13 August 2014|work=[[BBC News]]|date=7 June 2014}} On 14 March 2014, a married couple from London – who pleaded guilty to disseminating a terrorist publication – were jailed for posting videos on YouTube which condoned the death of Lee Rigby, with one video describing it as a "brilliant day".{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-26579717 |title=Lee Rigby murder: Couple jailed for glorification videos |work=BBC News |date=14 March 2014}}{{cite news|last=Pennink|first=Emily|title=Lee Rigby murder: Royal Barnes pleads guilty to posting videos online glorifying the death|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/lee-rigby-murder-royal-barnes-pleads-guilty-to-posting-videos-online-glorifying-the-death-9124199.html|accessdate=1 May 2014|newspaper=The Independent (UK) |date=12 February 2014}} ===Anti-Muslim backlash=== In the aftermath of the attack, an anti-Muslim backlash occurred across the United Kingdom.{{cite news|title=Woolwich attack provokes anti-Muslim backlash across UK|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10080300/Woolwich-attack-provokes-anti-Muslim-backlash-across-UK.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=25 May 2013}} A representative of [[Hope not Hate]] said the number of phone calls to its helpline concerning anti-Muslim incidents greatly increased after the murder. Hope not Hate reported 193 [[Islamophobia|Islamophobic]] incidents, including attacks on 10 mosques, as of 27 May.{{cite news|title=Woolwich murder: 200 Islamophobic incidents since Lee Rigby's killing|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2013/may/28/woolwich-murder-200-islamophobic-incidences|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 May 2013|accessdate=12 June 2013|first1=Matthew|last1=Taylor|first2=Haroon|last2= Siddique}} On 1 June, [[Tell MAMA UK|Tell MAMA]], a government-funded project, reported 212 anti-Muslim incidents, including 125 online incidents, 17 incidents involving physical attack, and 11 attacks on mosques.{{cite news | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10093568/The-truth-about-the-wave-of-attacks-on-Muslims-after-Woolwich-murder.html | title = The truth about the 'wave of attacks on Muslims’ after Woolwich murder |authorlink1=Andrew Gilligan| first1 = Andrew | last1= Gilligan | newspaper= [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 1 June 2013 }} It was reported on 9 June that government funding for Tell MAMA would not be renewed, due to concern over the reliability of data reported by the organisation, although the decision had been made before Rigby's death.{{cite news|url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/journalists/andrew-gilligan/10108098/Muslim-hate-monitor-to-lose-backing.html|title= Muslim hate monitor to lose backing|newspaper= The Sunday Telegraph|first1= Andrew|last1= Gilligan|authorlink1=Andrew Gilligan|date= 9 June 2013|accessdate= 12 June 2013}} Incidents ranged from verbal abuse to physical assaults in which women's headscarves were pulled off. Graffiti was scrawled over mosques and Muslim-owned businesses.{{cite news|title=Call for Calm After 3 New Arrests in British Soldier's Death|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/26/world/europe/anti-muslim-threats-rise-in-britain-after-soldiers-killing.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=23 May 2013}} Hope not Hate claimed that online activity suggested some of the attacks on Muslims were co-ordinated. At least seven people were arrested for a range of social media-related issues.{{cite news | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22664835 | title = Woolwich murder sparks anti-Muslim backlash |publisher = BBC News | date = 25 May 2013 | accessdate = 26 May 2013 }} During the night after Rigby's death, two mosques were attacked. controversy=== Video footage of one of the perpetrators justifying the killing of Lee Rigby was obtained by ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' and [[ITN]].Hollander, Gavriel (24 May 2013). [http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/sun-and-itv-defend-public-interest-broadcasting-woolwich-terror-video-which-sky-news-judged-too "Sun and ITV defend 'public interest' in showing Woolwich terror video Sky judged too 'distressing'"]. ''Press Gazette''. ITN's video, which was edited before it was broadcast,Halliday, Josh (24 May 2013). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2013/may/24/woolwich-attack-itv-michael-adebolajo-confession "Woolwich attack: ITV removes content from suspect's video 'confession'"]. ''The Guardian''. aired during the 18:30 ''ITV News'' bulletin before the 21:00 [[Watershed (broadcasting)#United Kingdom|watershed]], and again in its 22:00 bulletin. After being posted on the ITN website in the afternoon, the high level of visits caused the site to crash and go offline for around half an hour. Total traffic on the site, which averages 860,000 unique users per week, reached 1.2 million for the day of the attack. Managing editor of ''The Sun'', Richard Caseby, said the newspaper had faced "a very difficult decision". Both media outlets argued they had released the video "in the public interest". [[BBC News]] showed some parts of the video. [[Sky News]] decided not to follow suit, as senior editors were of the opinion that the graphic images were "unnecessarily distressing". Both ITV and the BBC ran warnings before showing the footage. Most of Britain's national daily newspapers grabbed still images from the video footage for their front pages the next morning. A BBC executive said that the news organisation edited the footage before broadcasting, and "dealt with the material as carefully as we could." The spokesman said they "thought very carefully about the pictures… and gave great consideration to how we used the footage". They argued that the footage was an important element of the story and shed light on the perpetrators and the possible motives for the attack." ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported there were "around 800 complaints from distressed viewers". Most complaints were targeted at the television coverage, with ITV receiving 400 complaints in the 24 hours following the broadcast.Stephen Lepitak, (23 May 2013). [http://www.thedrum.com/news/2013/05/23/itv-receives-400-complaints-over-woolwich-terrorism-video-report-featuring-bloodied "ITV receives 400 complaints over Woolwich terrorism video report featuring bloodied assailant"] ''The Drum''. Sky News, which showed a still image of one of the suspected attackers with bloodied hands, received "a handful of complaints". On 17 June, the broadcasting standards watchdog [[Ofcom]] launched an investigation into broadcast of footage from the attack after receiving about 700 complaints.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22938744 |publisher=BBC News |title=Ofcom investigates broadcasting of Lee Rigby footage |date=17 June 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2013}} Ofcom published its findings on 6 January 2014, ruling that the news footage had not breached broadcasting regulations. Ofcom issued new guidelines to news outlets on giving appropriate warnings before airing distressing content.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-25624599 |work=BBC News |title=Ofcom clears news coverage of Lee Rigby murder |publisher=BBC |date=6 January 2014 |accessdate=6 January 2014}} ===Anti-terrorism task force=== The UK government established a task force to look at ways of stemming the growth of Islamic extremism in Britain, focusing on the radicalisation of worshippers in mosques, university students and prisoners. The task force – chaired by David Cameron – had its inaugural meeting at [[10 Downing Street]] on 3 June 2013, and includes [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet Ministers]], and representatives from the police and intelligence services. Later that day Cameron made a [[House of Commons (United Kingdom)|House of Commons]] statement on the Woolwich attack, saying that lessons must be learned. "When young men born and bred in this country are radicalised and turned into killers, we have to ask some tough questions about what is happening in our country. It is as if that for some young people there is a conveyor belt to radicalisation that has poisoned their minds with sick and perverted ideas. We need to dismantle this process at every stage – in schools, colleges, universities, on the internet, in our prisons, wherever it is taking place."{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22756225 |title= Woolwich killing a betrayal of Islam, says Cameron|publisher= BBC News|date= 3 June 2013|accessdate= 6 June 2013}} ===Parliamentary inquiry=== On 25 November 2014, the findings of a British parliamentary inquiry into the murder of Lee Rigby were published. The report found that the death could not have been prevented, although his killers had appeared in seven intelligence investigations.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-30192912 |title=Woolwich murder: Lee Rigby's death 'not preventable'|publisher= BBC News|date= 25 November 2014|accessdate= 25 November 2014}}"[http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/11/26/world/europe/document-report-on-the-intelligence-relating-to-the-murder-of-fusilier-lee-rigby.html Report on the Intelligence Relating to the Murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby]" [[Intelligence and Security Committee of Parliament|Intelligence and Security Committee]], 25 November 2014. In December 2012, Michael Adebowale had discussed killing a soldier on [[Facebook]] with a foreign-based extremist known as "Foxtrot". The UK authorities did not have access to the details of the conversation until June 2013, when they were disclosed to [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]].{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/london/2014-11-25/lee-rigby-murder-internet-company-accused-of-being-a-safe-haven-for-terrorists/ |title=Lee Rigby murder: Internet company accused of being a 'safe haven for terrorists'|publisher= ITV News|date= 25 November 2014|accessdate= 27 November 2014}} The [[Intelligence and Security Committee of Parliament|Intelligence and Security Committee]] stated "Had [[MI5]] had access to this exchange, their investigation into Adebowale would have become a top priority."{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-30199131 |title=Facebook hosted Lee Rigby death chat ahead of soldier's murder|publisher= BBC News|date= 25 November 2014|accessdate= 25 November 2014}} Facebook said that it did not comment on individual cases, but responded that "Facebook’s policies are clear, we do not allow terrorist content on the site and take steps to prevent people from using our service for these purposes."{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/facebook-was-firm-that-failed-to-tell-uk-intelligence-about-adebowale-threats-9882842.html|title=Facebook was firm that 'failed to tell UK intelligence about Michael Adebowale threats'|work= [[The Independent]]|date= 25 November 2014|accessdate= 25 November 2014}} In an interview with BBC News on 26 November 2014, [[Richard Barrett (counter-terrorism expert)|Richard Barrett]], the former Director of Global Counter-terrorism at [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]], said that it was unfair to expect companies to monitor websites for all potentially extremist content. Facebook had blocked seven of Adebowale's accounts prior to the killing, five of which had been flagged for links with extremism. The accounts had been flagged by an automated process, and no person at Facebook had manually checked the accounts.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-30206359 |title=Woolwich murder: Facebook criticism 'unfair', former MI6 director says|publisher= BBC News|date= 26 November 2014|accessdate= 26 November 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/nov/26/lee-rigby-former-counter-terror-chief-criticism-facebook-unfair |title=Ex-counter-terror chief: criticism of Facebook over Rigby murder is unfair|work= The Guardian|date= 26 November 2014|accessdate= 26 November 2014}} ==Reactions== Queen [[Elizabeth II]], political leaders and religious leaders variously expressed concern and distress over the incident, and called for calm. Prime Minister David Cameron made the following statement:
This country will be absolutely resolute in its stand against extremism and terror. This action was a betrayal of Islam and the Muslim communities that give so much to our country. We will defeat violent extremism by standing together. We will not rest until we know every detail. [The attackers told Ingrid Loyau-Kennett that] they wanted to start a war in London and she replied, "You are going to lose, it is you against many." She speaks for all of us.
Many Muslim leaders denounced the attack. The Prime Minister's statement was echoed by Shaykh [[Ibrahim Mogra]], with the Archbishop of Canterbury, [[Justin Welby]], the co-chair of the Christian Muslim Forum, in a joint statement.{{cite news |title=Archbishop praises faith groups response to Woolwich attack|first=Jennifer|last=O'Mahony|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10078941/Archbishop-praises-faith-groups-response-to-Woolwich-attack.html|publisher=The Telegraph|date=24 May 2013|accessdate=18 Nov 2016}} The [[Muslim Council of Britain]] said the attack "has no basis in Islam and we condemn this unreservedly". The head of the Ramadhan Foundation, [[Mohammed Shafiq]], also condemned the attack. The director of [[Faith Matters]] and co-ordinator of the government-backed anti-Islamophobic project [[Tell MAMA UK|Tell MAMA]] stated: "We, as the Muslim community, will work against anyone who promotes such hatred." [[Anjem Choudary]] refused to condemn the attack. He said, "I'm not in the business of condemnation or condoning. I think if anyone needs to be condemned it is the British government and their foreign policy. It's so clear that that is the cause."{{cite news|last=Holden |first=Michael |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/23/us-britain-killing-choudary-idUSBRE94M0OZ20130523 |title=Head of radical Islamist group who knew London knifeman blames UK foreign policy |agency=Reuters |date=17 May 2013}} On BBC's ''Newsnight'', when Choudary was questioned about his role in the radicalisation of Michael Adebolajo, he denied any responsibility, and talked about such radicalisation as a means to an end. He stated that he believed that not many Muslims would disagree with what Adebolajo had said in his videoed statement.{{cite news|title=Anjem Choudary refuses to 'abhor' Woolwich attack|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22650053|accessdate=24 May 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=24 May 2013}} [[Asghar Bukhari]] of the UK [[Muslim Public Affairs Committee]] said that both the British Government and the Muslim community were at fault in dealing with "extremism". He criticised the British Government for being involved in wars in Iraq and Afghanistan while "completely denying that it has anything to do with the political situation around the Muslim world", and said that Muslim organisations "have failed their own community by not teaching these young, angry men how to get a democratic change to this policy that's ruining so many lives". He described Muslim leaders as unwilling to bring about change, focussing on points of theology, rather than the practical education of young people in ways to achieve political change.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/23/world/europe/uk-attack-muslims/index.html|title=UK Muslim groups condemn London slaying, urge leaders to act|date=23 May 2013|publisher=CNN}} [[Pauline Neville-Jones, Baroness Neville-Jones|Baroness Neville-Jones]], a former security minister and chairman of the [[Joint Intelligence Committee (United Kingdom)|British Joint Intelligence Committee]], and Colonel [[Richard Kemp]], a former Army commander, suggested blame could be put on internet hate preaching. Neville-Jones told the [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Today (BBC Radio 4)|Today]]'' programme that "the inspiration that comes from internet hate preaching and jihadist rhetoric… is a very, very serious problem now."{{cite web|last=Dominiczak|first=Peter|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10075306/Woolwich-attack-We-must-tackle-hate-preaching-over-the-internet-security-experts-say.html|title=Woolwich attack: We must tackle hate preaching over the internet, security experts say|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=23 May 2013|accessdate=23 May 2013}} [[George Galloway]], then an MP, said that the attack on Lee Rigby was "indefensible". He criticised British support for the [[Syrian opposition|Syrian rebels]], stating that similar attacks are likely to occur "as long as we are, as a country, involved in spreading murder and mayhem across the Muslim world."{{cite news|first=Gareth| last=Platt|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/470541/20130523/woolwich-beheading-murder-edl-george-galloway.htm|title=George Galloway: Woolwich Beheading Attack will be Repeated, EDL are 'Moral Dwarves'|date=23 May 2013|newspaper=IBT}}Fisher, Max (22 May 2013). [http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/05/22/british-politician-compares-london-attack-to-u-k-policy-in-syria/ British politician compares London machete attack to U.K. policy in Syria]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''.[http://rt.com/op-edge/woolwich-attack-radicalized-muslims-galloway-718/ ‘We built Frankenstein monsters, spawned millions of radicalized Muslims’ – MP George Galloway], [[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]], 24 May 2013. Former UK Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] saw the attack not as an isolated expression of two crazed individuals but part of the broader "problem within Islam".{{cite news|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/lee-rigby-and-the-struggle-to-contain-violent-islamists-by-tony-blair|title=The Trouble Within Islam|date=10 June 2013|author=Tony Blair|newspaper=Project Syndicate}} In foreign press reports there was widespread outrage and condemnation of the killing. Yusif al-Shihab, in [[Kuwait]]'s ''Al-Abas'', stated that the assailants have "deformed the image of Islam" while Batir Mohammad Wardum in the [[Jordan]]ian daily ''[[Ad-Dustour (Jordan)|Al-Dustur]]'', and other Middle Eastern newspapers, stressed that their actions have endangered the lives of thousands of Muslims. The killing triggered a public outpouring of grief and hundreds of bunches of flowers, teddy bears, poems and other tributes were left near the scene of the crime.{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2330219/Woolwich-attack-Outpouring-grief-murdered-Lee-Rigby-stream-strangers-leave-tributes-street-died.html#ixzz2YrJt5tFA |title=RIP brave soldier: Outpouring of grief for murdered Lee Rigby as stream of strangers leave their tributes on street where he died |author=Rosie Taylor |publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |date=24 May 2013 |accessdate=12 July 2013}} In a statement issued on 28 May, Adebolajo's relatives condemned terrorism and violence in the name of religion, and expressed their horror at Rigby's death. In October 2013 British anti-terrorist police warned several Muslims who had spoken out against Islamist extremism, some of them explicitly against the murder of Rigby, that they had been targeted in a video created by [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]], the group responsible for the [[Westgate shopping mall attack|attack on the Westgate shopping mall]] in Kenya.{{cite web|author=Simon Hooper |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/10/british-muslims-defiant-over-al-shabab-threat-2013102591313719196.html |title=British Muslims defiant over al-Shabab threat |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date= |accessdate=6 November 2013}} ==Attempted copycat cases== On 19 February 2015, 19-year-old Brusthom Ziamani was found guilty of preparing a terrorist act. He was arrested in London in August 2014 while carrying a 12-inch knife, hammer and black [[Black Standard#Jihadist black flag|jihadist flag]]. Ziamani had said that he intended to attack and kill soldiers, and had described Adebolajo as a "legend".{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31540281 |title=Brusthom Ziamani: Teenager guilty of plot to behead soldier|publisher= BBC News|date= 19 February 2015|accessdate= 20 February 2015}} On 20 March Ziamani was sentenced to 22 years in prison.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31987242 |title=Soldier beheading plan teenager Brusthom Ziamani jailed|publisher= BBC News|date= 20 March 2015|accessdate= 20 March 2015}} On 29 April 2015, 18-year-old Kazi Islam, who was inspired by the murder, was convicted by a jury at the Old Bailey of grooming a vulnerable friend to kill two soldiers, and buying ingredients for a [[pipe bomb]].{{cite news|title=Teenager Kazi Islam found guilty of terror grooming|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-32521780|accessdate=29 April 2015|work=BBC News|date=29 April 2015}} On 29 May, he was sentenced to eight years in a young offenders' institution.{{cite news|title=Teenager Kazi Islam jailed for 'terror grooming'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-32936947|accessdate=1 June 2015|work=BBC News|date=29 May 2015}} On 14 January 2015, 26-year-old [[White supremacy|white supremacist]] Zack Davies of [[Mold, Flintshire]] attacked a [[Sikh]] dentist in a [[Tesco]] supermarket with a machete and a hammer. He claimed in court that the attack was revenge for the murder of Rigby.{{cite news|title='Lee Rigby revenge' attacker guilty of attempted murder|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-north-east-wales-33252264|accessdate=25 June 2015|work=BBC News|date=25 June 2015}} Davies was sentenced to life imprisonment on 11 September 2015.{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby revenge attacker Zack Davies given life sentence|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-north-east-wales-34218184|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=BBC News|date=12 September to the Armed Forces Memorial at the [[National Memorial Arboretum]].[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2653435/Lee-Rigbys-engraved-Britains-largest-military-memorial.html Lee Rigby's name engraved into Britain's largest military memorial | Mail Online]{{cite news|title=Lee Rigby honoured at National Memorial Arboretum|url=http://www.itv.com/news/granada/update/2014-09-01/lee-rigby-honoured-at-national-memorial-arboretum/|work=ITV News|accessdate=1 September 2014|date=1 September 2014}} A memorial to Rigby in his home town of Middleton, Greater Manchester, consisting of a bronze drum and a plaque, was unveiled on 29 March 2015.{{cite news|title=Monument to Lee Rigby unveiled in murdered soldier's home town|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/mar/29/monument-lee-rigby-murdered-woolwich-soldiers-home-town-middleton|accessdate=16 April 2015|work=The Guardian|date=29 March 2015}} Plans for a memorial to Rigby in Woolwich initially ran into opposition from local MP [[Nick Raynsford]], who expressed concerns that it would generate "undesirable interest from extremists" or become a target for vandals."[http://www.itv.com/news/london/2014-05-22/boris-backs-calls-for-a-memorial-to-honour-lee-rigby/ Boris backs calls for a memorial to honour Lee Rigby]" 22 May 2014. Retrieved 12 June 2014. [[Greenwich London Borough Council|Greenwich Council]] said that it had not received a request from the Army to erect a memorial at the site."[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-27500060 Lee Rigby murder: Calls for Woolwich memorial rejected]" BBC News, 21 May 2014. Retrieved 12 June 2014. Meanwhile, the site of the murder on Wellington Street developed into an unofficial memorial site. Following a campaign for a memorial supported by [[Boris Johnson]] and a petition with 25,000 signatures, plans for a memorial near the site of the attack were announced on 11 June 2014.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/10893716/Lee-Rigby-memorial-victory-at-last-for-campaigners.html Lee Rigby memorial: victory at last for campaigners – Telegraph] The memorial was revealed on 11 November 2015 after considerable delays, as "the council had had to balance different opinions about how Lee Rigby should be commemorated".[http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-34307605 Lee Rigby memorial plaque approved for Greenwich], 20 September 2015, and [http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-34779650 Lee Rigby honoured on memorial plaque unveiled in Woolwich], 11 November 2015, on ''bbc.com''. Lee Rigby's name appears on a plaque on the south wall of the memorial garden inside the ruined [[St George's Garrison Church, Woolwich|St George's Garrison Church]] in Woolwich, opposite the [[Royal Artillery Barracks]]. The memorial consists of a white marble plaque marking Woolwich's history as a barracks town, and two bronze plaques with the names of 11 men who served or lived in Woolwich and gave their lives in the service of their country, including Rigby and the victims of the 1974 [[Kings Arms, Woolwich|King's Arms bombing]] nearby.Full list on [http://e-shootershill.co.uk/woolwich-remembers/ Woolwich remembers] on ''e-shootershill.co.uk'', 10 November 2015. ==See also== *[[Udham Singh]] -
